<a href="https://www.gitbook.com/?utm_source=content&amp;utm_medium=trademark&amp;utm_campaign=-MkP23pBP3MWkIzJcreW" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1uwl36a r-z2wwpe r-1rasi3h r-1loqt21 r-18u37iz r-1fdo3w0 r-1mnahxq r-ymttw5 r-5njf8e r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-eu3ka r-1aockid" /></a>

Powered By <span class="css-901oao css-16my406 r-b88u0q">GitBook</span>

What's Inclusive Design?

Inclusive design is a philosophy that a product should be "accessible to, and usable by, as many people as reasonably possible ... without the need for special adaptation or specialized design" (Briti

# 

<span key="40f30e11626d4c3981e14383c3b0c3f1"><span offset-key="40f30e11626d4c3981e14383c3b0c3f1:0">What's Inclusive Design?</span></span>

<span key="a5ccdd73f5824101b43d99679c20ef47">**Inclusive design**<span offset-key="a5ccdd73f5824101b43d99679c20ef47:1"> is a philosophy that a product should be "accessible to, and usable by, as many people as reasonably possible ... without the need for special adaptation or specialized design" (</span></span><a href="https://shop.bsigroup.com/products/design-management-systems-managing-inclusive-design-guide?pid=000000000030142267" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d812e90460fb42fbb88d1ff0fb72d445" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-40461_259-40462-237__"><span data-key="fd25b43c77f34ac18d0da18ea51777f2"><span data-offset-key="fd25b43c77f34ac18d0da18ea51777f2:0">British Standards Institute (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="654e47da806e4857983b978f06195a61"><span offset-key="654e47da806e4857983b978f06195a61:0">, 2005).</span></span>

<span key="1520cabf4ef84162820237206718ec2d"><span offset-key="1520cabf4ef84162820237206718ec2d:0">In short, we shouldn't need to adapt products after the fact to handle certain "special" groups of users (e.g., those with visual impairments, those with low language or tech literacy). Instead, we should try to design our product, from the start, to accommodate them in a first-class way.</span></span>

## 

<span key="8f5e1551c6f44882a5b0f0b9ddce51da"><span offset-key="8f5e1551c6f44882a5b0f0b9ddce51da:0">Designing Inclusively</span></span>

<span key="f536e789d25b4d4892729887ea37cbcf"><span offset-key="f536e789d25b4d4892729887ea37cbcf:0">Inclusive design </span>*doesn't*<span offset-key="f536e789d25b4d4892729887ea37cbcf:2"> mean we'll be able to design perfectly for every single person who might use our product. After all, it would be impossible to anticipate every possible way in with people might differ and in which their experience with a product might be affected.</span></span>

<span key="627fa9c844374aa98ba2da28618097c3"><span offset-key="627fa9c844374aa98ba2da28618097c3:0">Instead, we can only do our best to make an effort to </span>*understand the diversity*<span offset-key="627fa9c844374aa98ba2da28618097c3:2"> of our potential users as we develop our product, and apply that understanding to our design.</span></span>

<span key="676e659267a249c795272eb9e630e026"><span offset-key="676e659267a249c795272eb9e630e026:0">We can then consciously incorporate different ways for users to interact with our product.</span></span>

<span key="d8b7fe5761de42c5a3d2f6b42d39caba"><span offset-key="d8b7fe5761de42c5a3d2f6b42d39caba:0">And then regardless, we should make it easy to adapt or extend our product for those we weren't initially able to design for.</span></span>

<span key="439697b2a2a84eeab260de25216b4382"><span offset-key="439697b2a2a84eeab260de25216b4382:0">For example, Microsoft's </span></span><a href="https://www.microsoft.com/design/inclusive/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3de75ad50cee4a2891cd2a0f5d3f4679" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-40461_259-40462-237__"><span data-key="25f64a3fcfd54fc889d14c6abfcefc93"><span data-offset-key="25f64a3fcfd54fc889d14c6abfcefc93:0">resources on inclusive design (Links to an external site.)</span></span></span></a><span key="ed62e5b249ac4d04b40c2274897cec44"><span offset-key="ed62e5b249ac4d04b40c2274897cec44:0"> lays out three principles of inclusive design:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="3a3bc357c5b64dddb189e342ba180aa3"><span offset-key="3a3bc357c5b64dddb189e342ba180aa3:0">Recognize exclusion</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="f9ccf302a8734b0bb9d102063bfebfcd"><span offset-key="f9ccf302a8734b0bb9d102063bfebfcd:0">Solve for one, extend to many</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="d487cdb4abc34ae4ae54df9890d0356f"><span offset-key="d487cdb4abc34ae4ae54df9890d0356f:0">Learn from diversity</span></span>

<span key="0871b79f8e9a476bb5fb9446f1f8e1c1"><span offset-key="0871b79f8e9a476bb5fb9446f1f8e1c1:0">If we designed a product based on simply our own perspective and abilities, we'd be producing a product biased heavily toward people just like us. What about the rest? What factors might you consider?</span></span>

<a href="../design.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1awozwy r-14lw9ot r-190qawg r-z2wwpe r-rs99b7 r-4dj0k7 r-1loqt21 r-1quu1zo r-1ro0kt6 r-18u37iz r-16y2uox r-1wbh5a2 r-nsbfu8 r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"></a>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1rasi3h r-1472mwg r-lrsllp" />
